definitions.definition: the part of the human body that is on the opposite side to the chest, between the neck and the tops of the legs; the part of an animal’s body that corresponds to this
definitions.sensetop: on your backwith your back to somebody/somethingbehind your backat your backin your/the back
definitions.labels: (informal)(formal)(British English)(British English)(disapproving)(both informal, often disapproving)(informal, disapproving)

examples.text: He was lying on his back on the sofa.
Do you sleep on your back or your front?
She was standing with her back to the camera so you can't see her face.
They stood with their hands behind their backs.
They set off with the wind at their backs *(= behind them)*.
your lower/upper back
I have a nagging pain in my lower back.
The ball hit him in the back.
a bad *(= painful)* back
I pulled *(= injured the muscles in)* my back playing squash.
She was laid up with severe **back pain**.
A small boy rode on the elephant's back.
He stood with his back to the door.
a back massage
He was carrying a small child on his back.
They blindfolded him and tied his hands behind his back.
He was standing with his back to the fire.
He smiled and gave me a hearty slap on the back.
He yawned and stretched his back as he got out of bed.
The cat arched its back and hissed at the dog.
He hunches his back when he walks.
His back stiffened as he saw the photographers waiting.
He leaned his back against the bar.
He's in bed with a bad back.
I was flat on my back for six weeks when I broke my leg.
She felt a sharp pain in the small of her back.
The sun beat down on their bare backs.
Would you give me a back rub?
I need a seat with good back support.

definitions.definition: the row of bones in the middle of the back

examples.text: She broke her back in a riding accident.
He spent six months recovering from a **broken back**.
He **put his back out** *(=  something in his back)* lifting the crates.

definitions.definition: the part or area of something that is furthest from the front
definitions.sensetop: at the backin the backin backaround the back

examples.text: She was hit on the **back of the head**.
He kicked the ball straight into the **back of the net**.
The man was refusing to go to the back of the queue.
The house has three bedrooms at the front and two at the back.
We could only get seats at the back *(= of a room)*.
There's room for three people in the back *(= of a car, etc.)*.
There's room for three people in back.
Come around the back *(= to the area behind the house)* and I'll show you the garden.
He was hit in the back of the knee.
I found some old photos at the back of the drawer.
They were sitting in the back of the truck.
My money's all fallen down the back of the cushion.
The cup had been pushed to the back of the cupboard.
Two passengers sat in the back of the car.

definitions.definition: the part of a piece of paper, etc. that is on the opposite side to the one that has information or the most important information on it
definitions.sensetop: on the backon the back of something

examples.text: Take a card and write your name on the back.
He scribbled some figures on the back of an envelope.

definitions.definition: the last few pages of a book, etc.
definitions.sensetop: at the back (of something)in the back (of something)towards the back (of something)

examples.text: The index is at the back of the journal.
The answer key is in the back of the book.
The article I mentioned is in that magazine—towards the back I think.
The arts page is usually towards the back of the newspaper.

definitions.definition: the part of a chair, etc. against which you lean your back
used to describe furniture that has the type of back mentioned

examples.text: a high-backed sofa

definitions.definition: a player whose main role is to defend their team’s goal
if a thought, etc. is at the back of your mind, you are aware of it but it is not what you are mainly thinking about

examples.text: At the back of my mind was a small, warning voice, telling me it was wrong.
The problem was always at the back of my mind.

definitions.definition: when somebody's back is turned they are not present and not able to see what is happening

examples.text: Officers are ready to issue a parking ticket as soon as a driver's back is turned.

definitions.definition: a place that is a long way from other houses, towns, etc.

examples.text: We stayed in some farmhouse in the back of beyond.

definitions.definition: used to talk about planning or calculating something in a way that is not detailed, exact or complete

examples.text: We added up our savings on the back of an envelope.
**back-of-the-envelope calculations**

definitions.definition: if two people stand or sit back to back, they stand or sit with their backs facing or touching each other

examples.text: The children sat back to back so they couldn't see each others' drawings.

definitions.definition: if two or more things happen back to back, they happen one after the other

examples.text: The team had to play three games back to back.

definitions.definition: if you put on a piece of clothing back to front, you make a mistake and put the back where the front should be

examples.text: I think you've got that sweater on back to front.

definitions.definition: to be happy that you will not have to deal with or see somebody/something again because you do not like them or it

examples.text: Was I pleased to see the back of her!
I can’t wait to see the back of that old car.

definitions.definition: without somebody’s knowledge or permission

examples.text: Have you been talking about me behind my back?
They went ahead and sold it behind my back.
People say bad things about him behind his back, but never to his face.

definitions.definition: to keep asking or telling somebody to do something that they do not want to do, in a way that they find annoying

examples.text: He’s still on my back about that money I borrowed.

definitions.definition: to finish the largest or most important part of a task

examples.text: I want to break the back of this translation before the weekend.

definitions.definition: to realize that you may be blamed or criticized for something later and take action to avoid this

examples.text: Get everything in writing in order to cover your back.

definitions.definition: to annoy somebody

examples.text: That sort of attitude really gets my back up!

definitions.definition: to stop annoying somebody, for example by criticizing them, or asking them to do something

examples.text: Just get off my back, will you!

definitions.definition: to protect and support somebody

examples.text: Don't worry, I've got your back.
I’m loyal and I’ve got your back.

definitions.definition: to be in a difficult situation in which you are forced to do something but are unable to make the choices that you would like

examples.text: We had our backs to the wall with no choice but to sell.

definitions.definition: to be aware of everything that is happening around you, even things that seem difficult or impossible to see

examples.text: You can’t get away with anything in her class. She has eyes in the back of her head.

definitions.definition: to be very familiar with somebody/something

examples.text: This is where I grew up. I know this area like the back of my hand.

definitions.definition: the last in a series of bad events, etc. that makes it impossible for you to accept a situation any longer
to do something that will cause problems for you in the future
immediately after something

examples.text: They come into this game off the back of a 1–0 defeat to Chelsea.

definitions.definition: as a result of an achievement or a success

examples.text: The profits growth came on the back of a 26 per cent rise in sales.

definitions.definition: goods that fell off the back of a lorry were probably stolen. People say or accept that they came ‘off the back of a lorry’ to avoid saying or asking where they really came from.
in bed because you are ill

examples.text: She's been flat on her back for over a week now.
The UK market was flat on its back *(= business was very bad)*.

definitions.definition: praise or approval for something that you have done well

examples.text: He deserves a pat on the back for all his hard work.
Give yourself a pat on the back!

definitions.definition: to praise somebody or yourself for doing something well
to try to forget about something unpleasant

examples.text: I tried to push the thought to the back of my mind.

definitions.definition: to use a lot of effort and energy on a particular task
anything that somebody has, including the things they really need themselves, that somebody else takes from them or they are willing to give

examples.text: He was the type of person who would give you the shirt off his back.

definitions.definition: an act that harms somebody, done by a person they thought was a friend

examples.text: Her refusal to support his campaign was a real stab in the back.

definitions.definition: to do or say something that harms somebody who trusts you
to turn so that you are facing in the opposite direction
to move so that you are standing or sitting with your back facing somebody/something

examples.text: When on stage, try not to turn your back on the audience.

definitions.definition: to reject somebody/something that you have previously been connected with

examples.text: She turned her back on them when they needed her.
More and more people are turning their backs on meat and becoming vegetarians or vegans.
She decided to turn her back on Paris and return home.

definitions.definition: to protect yourself against danger

examples.text: She'd better watch her back if she wants to hold onto the top job.

definitions.definition: used to say that something, especially criticism, has no effect on somebody/something

examples.text: I can't tell my son what to do; it's water off a duck's back with him.

definitions.definition: used to say that if somebody helps you, you will help them, even if this is unfair to others

wordOrigin: Old English bæc, of Germanic origin; related to Middle Dutch and Old Norse bak. The adverb use dates from late Middle English and is a shortening of aback.
